title: How do your beliefs influence your understanding? - Quora

response.answer_text: Knowledge is “justified true belief.” A belief is an idea about reality, true or false. Ideas are statements about perceived reality. Truth is what corresponds to reality, so if a person holds a false belief, he is disoriented or disconnected from reality. One’s understanding is a consequence of his beliefs as they form his belief system. We interpret reality according to our belief system or worldview, an interpretive framework or outlook. The Christian belief system, with God in the equation, is relevant to all of life as an all-encompassing worldview and outlook, not just a religion. If you are negative or pessimistic, it will skew your understanding of reality. People can be biased due to false beliefs or understandings. It is unfortunate to not understand realty or the truth, because misbehavior results as a consequence. If you are righty interpreting reality, your understanding will be accurate and oriented to the truth. This is why Jesus claimed; “I am the truth.” He came to bear witness of the truth and told us it can set us free. If He is right, then the only valid interpretation of reality would be the Christian worldview. Many people hijack their faiths and become fanatics and even cause evil in the name of their God or religion. Being sincere, is no excuse for people can be sincerely wrong. NB: All ideas have consequences and no one can resist an idea whose time has come. There is a season and a time for every event under heaven.

If our beliefs is strong enough in our heart it can influence our perception of the world around us and determine how we talk to and treat others. When those beliefs belong to a larger group such as a culture, nationality, race, or religion then the impact can be much greater. For example, if you believe in evolution, you may think of “survival of the fittest.” Looking out only for your interests and that of your kind or group. If anyone suffer because of your actions it's because they are the weaker species--natural selection—too bad for them. If your religious belief teach you that you belong to a superior or master race then you will act accordingly and mistreat and oppress those who are different than you are. If you believe in an Almighty but loving God you will do your best to treat people the way He would want you to. Of course, most people are not guided by just a single belief but rather a combinations of belief systems such as cultural, religious (or lack of it), political, etc. History is full of these examples. We can honestly examine what we believe and be open-minded enough to talk about what we believe. Hopefully discard wrong and harmful beliefs and learn new ones that can benefit all of us.

Hello, Beliefs are an interesting thing because they shape our worldview and can distort how we perceive reality. A lot of people like to think that their beliefs are based on lived experiences, however that concept is fundamentally flawed. Every one was raised by adults, other humans that held their own beliefs and convictions. Growing up, many of us had religion in our homes. We were taught what to believe in as if it was undeniable fact. Interacting with people who have different belief systems than us can be very sobering and open our eyes to the realization of just how wrong we might be. In my life, I have many beliefs but I strive to learn about the beliefs of others as well. When I find a belief I don't agree with, I look at what evidence there is to support it. If I can find concrete evidence that is contrary to my previously held belief, I change that belief and listen to the evidence. When faced with new information, it first passes through the filters of belief. Belief can be a very limiting and harmful thing, or it can add immense value and purpose to our lives. Being open minded and willing to learn about other belief systems ensures a constantly evolving and bettering existence for everyone in my opinion.

Your beliefs make your understanding susceptible to falling prey to unique types of cognitive biases, based on what your belief system is made up of and what it is that you are trying to understand. This can weaken the effectiveness of your logical thought process as you try to unpack and understand the info or situation you are faced with. So, knowing which cognitive biases { read List of cognitive biases - Wikipedia} you or the person you are trying to explain a concept to suffer from could help to deal with this “stuck” situation in learning or communication.

Knowing something can mean several things: you have a certain belief, you are convinced, you learned, you are certain, you're sure of… Many languages have different words for different ways of knowing: Gnosis is a feminine Greek noun which means "knowledge" or "awareness." It is often used for personal knowledge compared with intellectual knowledge (εἶδειν eídein), as with the French connaître compared with savoir, the Spanish conocer compared with saber, the Italian conoscere compared with sapere, the German kennen rather than wissen (thank you Wikipedia) There is a development from beliefs and convictions to being sure or scientific knowledge. You learn something that changes a belief to a certainty, you understand something that changes a belief to a certainty. But this is not an answer to your question because this is how understanding influences belief and your question is about belief influencing understanding… Belief can be a tremendous incentive to want to discover something: this will help you understand! On the other hand, if it's hard to believe something, you will have little incentive to try your best to understand it. The history of science has many examples of belief holding back understanding (ask Galileo) and on the other hand: beliefs have been the root of many great discoveries. So belief guides you, be aware of this. Does it hold you back or does it lead you to being a better person.

My beliefs were formed based on previous understandings and each new understanding is built upon previous understandings i.e. current beliefs. Establishing a new belief or understanding may require the putting aside or rejection of some previous belief(s) or understanding(s). It is my hope and goal to believe as many true things and as few false things as possible, which may require an ongoing modification of my understanding and thus my set of beliefs, no easy feat given how tenacious some beliefs are.

Without beliefs you have nothing. That doesn’t mean that beliefs are fantasies. It simply means that beliefs form the “worldview” that information explains As a result learning and experience become the elements necessary to take the information gathered and make the beliefs more coherent. At this stage the individual can incorporate that knowledge in a variety of scenarios, often with incomplete information

Our understanding is based on three things: what we know, what we believe, and what we feel. Each of these has a huge influence on how we see the world. See also: Stephen Sibbald's answer to What is faith? Stephen Sibbald's answer to Why do people believe things based on faith rather than fact?

Depending where your beliefs are coming from, if from within, understanding will be more clear to your beliefs, ,If coming from another ,,then the understanding might require to real look at where your beliefs come from ,,follow your instincts
Our veliefs hinder the acceptance of truth. In order to unveil the next layer of truth of ourselves we must let go of a previously held thought form that we call a belief.
Imagine a symbolic creek running through your mind. I conceive of the stepping stones accross the creek as your beliefs when you need them.
